'Vladimir Ivanovich Vernadsky' (, ; â 6 January 1945) was a Ukrainian and Soviet
mineralogist and geochemist who is considered one of the founders of
geochemistry, biogeochemistry, and of radiogeology. His ideas of noosphere were
an important contribution to Russian cosmism. He also worked in Ukraine, where
he founded the Ukrainian Academy of Sciences (now National Academy of Sciences
of Ukraine). He is most noted for his 1926 book The Biosphere in which he
inadvertently worked to popularize Eduard Suessâ 1885 term biosphere, by
hypothesizing that life is the geological force that shapes the earth. In 1943
he was awarded the Stalin Prize.
